bestBHT.bht: To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might shown in so 'perfecting' us. Giving Him glory shows gratitude for His grace bestowed upon us. Dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and dispenses grace in a sovereign way. Amen, signifying the belief in the prayer that the apostle prayed, trusting that it will be answered as they desire.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To Him and Him alone: not to ourselves.
The might shown in so 'perfecting,' you.
The oldest manuscripts and versions omit 'glory and dominion'.
Albert Barnes: To him be glory ... - See the notes at 1 Peter 4:11.
John Calvin: Though this be read in the indicative as well as in the optative mood, still the meaning is nearly the same.
Philip Schaff: To him be (or, is) the dominion unto the ages. Amen.
A doxology similar to that in chap. 1 Peter 4:11, but briefer.
The longer version of the A. V. is not sustained by sufficient evidence.
Archibald T. Robertson: To him (αυτω). To God (dative case). Note κρατος in the doxology as in 1 Timothy 6:16 and briefer than the doxology in 1 Peter 4:11, to Christ.
John Gill: Glory is due to God for all the grace he bestows on men and to give it to him shows a sense of divine goodness, and a grateful heart."
To him very fitly is 'dominion' ascribed, whose kingdom rules over all, and who dispenses his grace, as well as his providential favours, in a sovereign way.
Amen, signifying that so the apostle prayed it might be, and believed it would be.

bhtAttempts.bht: To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might shown in so 'perfecting' us. To Him be glory, as He deserves all the credit for the grace bestowed upon us. Though the longer version of the doxology is not supported by sufficient evidence, the briefer version still conveys the same meaning. Glory is due to God for His goodness towards us, and giving Him glory shows gratitude. Dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and dispenses grace in a sovereign way. Amen, signifying the apostle's belief in his prayer.

To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might shown in so 'perfecting' us. To Him be glory, as He deserves it for the grace bestowed. Giving Him glory shows gratitude and a sense of divine goodness. Dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and dispenses grace in a sovereign way. Amen, signifying the apostle's belief in his prayer.

To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might shown in so 'perfecting' us. The doxology, though the longer version is not supported by sufficient evidence, still conveys the same meaning. Glory is due to God for His goodness towards us, and giving Him glory shows gratitude. Dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and dispenses grace in a sovereign way. Amen, signifying the belief in the prayer.

To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the might shown in so 'perfecting' us. Giving Him glory shows gratitude for His grace bestowed upon us. Dominion is ascribed to Him, whose kingdom rules over all and dispenses grace in a sovereign way. Amen, signifying the belief in the prayer that the apostle prayed, trusting that it will be answered as they desire.

To Him and Him alone, not to ourselves, be the glory and dominion. This doxology, though briefer than the one in 1 Peter 4:11, is a heartfelt expression of thanksgiving, acknowledging that it is to God that all grace is due and that His kingdom rules over all. It is a proclamation of faith, believing that God will indeed receive the glory and have dominion forever. Amen.
